data.text: Listening to Music while Touring by Bike

For those who listen to music on the road. These are my recent discoveries on the path to two wheeled musical enlightenment. I would like to hear other people‚Äôs experiences comparing different audio options as well. I now own Bluetooth in-ear phones, bone conduction phones, and a Bluetooth speaker. All of which I have used on the bike. Here are my personal thoughts/findings. In-ear phones, are not advisable for riding. However, great for keeping out unwanted noise in restaurants, walking around, or relaxing in public areas. The dynamic range can also be pretty good, even with mid-priced phones. Bone induction phones. These do not have a good dynamic range, the bass is especially weak. But for general listening they are ok.They are easily audible at low volumes. To some degree these open phones can be used to isolate outside unwanted noise if they are played at the loud end of things. This is because my brain will focus on the strongest noise. However, that can be a negative thing, because if the music is played at higher volumes I cannot hear traffic approaching from behind until it is close, and if the music is loud very close. When noisy vehicles pass, they will drown out the music. The bone induction phones are also expensive and even the most expensive have a limited dynamic range. Bluetooth speaker. I mount mine on the handlebars with the speaker facing me. Although my speaker is only mono and pretty cheap, the dynamic range is pretty good. It was also the cheapest of the options. I can play music very loud and still hear traffic approaching from behind. Noisy vehicles will drown out the music. The downside is that you cannot listen privately, you can annoy other people, and they take up space on the handlebars. Although I like my new Shokz Open Run phones, I am torn and may well go back to using my Bluetooth speaker on the road, or at least keep it handy as an option for busier roads. What did you find using your music options?

Pretty much what I experience too. No single thing will work for all situations. I really appreciate a loud bluetooth speaker when riding offroad trails in bear country where I might not see another human all day!

data.text: I, too, have the full range of gadgets - Aftershokz bone conduction, Sony over-ear noise cancelling headphones, Bluetooth speaker and cheap wired earphones. As with most other engineering problems, there is no single perfect solution, everything is a matter of compromises. But in the end, I've gone away from listening to anything while riding. The only ones with acceptable sound quality for music, are the over-ear noise cancelling Sonys, and they're completely unsuitable for cycling - sweaty, can't be worn with a helmet and block out traffic sounds. I did try the Aftershokz for audio books and podcasts, but any traffic noise would drown out the sound and I'd lose track of what was being said. The speaker has the same problems, plus it's totally antisocial. But the total killer is the same factor others have mentioned - the road is sufficient entertainment and better than any audio option! Even without car noise, I would lose track of the stories! And I found that if I tried listening to music, I'd just "zone out" and not really hear it. Waste of effort, in other words. Nowadays I just have a pair of extremely cheap earphones ( free advertising swag! ) that I plug in to my navigator and wear in one ear only, and just for turning instructions when crossing unfamiliar cities.
data.author: Torsten Lif

data.text: I wouldn't agree music on a bike is a total waste. I listen to music as a distraction on long inclines, I put my head down and I find it stops me looking up the hill every 30 seconds wondering how much further I have to go. There are also some sections of road that I regularly ride that can get monotonous, that also benefit from distraction. On steeper inclines music helps me keep cadence and is a distraction from pain. In these cases music quality is not an issue for me. I agree that at times music from a speaker can be antisocial, but I can ride for many kilometers at a time without seeing anyone, other than vehicle drivers, and they can't hear my music anyway. If I am in a place where I think music would be annoying, I switch it off.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Like I said, a matter of compromises. And personal taste/preferences, of course. One major bugbear - to me - was that I often wouldn't take notice of some approaching noise source until it had already drowned my book/podcast. So I sometimes had to stop to jump the player app back 15 or 30 seconds. That broke my rythm more than anything. Of course, with music that you're familiar with, losing 30 seconds isn't a big deal. But I soon found that even on the quiet stretches, I wasn't really listening. So TO ME it was a total waste. Just another battery drain. Of course, you wouldn't even have asked your question if you'd felt the same way. That's fine, as long as you take responsibility and don't block out traffic sounds when it would put you in danger. Myself, I've got a kind of "mantra" that I discovered way back in the 90's. I get James Brown singing "I feel good" like an earworm and I pedal in pace with it on long climbs. I feel good (left right left right) I knew that I would (left right left right) Congratulations, you have now been infected with the same worm!

I know most of you are riding in a Western context, but where I've lived, you cannot expect a person to respond to a bicycle bell, announcement that you're passing, etc. After a certain age, due to hierarchical norms, people in my country no longer choose to listen to others. When you do announce that you're passing and they actually respond, frequently they step directly in front of you rather than off the trail, for reasons that are unknown to me.
